pages.text: Eoporpita medusa comes from the Upper Ediacaran, with fossils found from the Flinders Ranges, South Australia; Mackenzie Mountains, Canada and White Sea, Russia. Eoporpita is a discoidal form, rimmed with hair-like 'tentacles' that grew up to 16 cm in diameter.

This morphology has been the main point of contention, with interpretations for Eoporpita being a possible hydrozoan in the porpitidae family (the most accepted), a holdfast for another form, or a Foraminifera Xenophyophorean. The generic name derives from 'Porpita', a genus of hydrozoan in the family porpitidae, with the Greek word 'eo', to mean 'dawn' added on.
